qas.question: "Drug reps" are usually hired by what type of firms?
What law regulates drug marketing in the US?
Who do drug reps market to?
"US reps" are usually hired by what type of firms?
What law regulates drug marketing in some countries?
Who do US reps market to?
Who do US companies generally employ?

plausible_answers.text: the federal Prescription Drug Marketing Act of 1987

qas.question: What is marketing of media in the US regulated by?

context: Advertising is common in healthcare journals as well as through more mainstream media routes. In some countries, notably the US, they are allowed to advertise directly to the general public. <a0_0><b3_0>Pharmaceutical companies<b3_0/><a0_0/> generally employ <b6_0>sales people<b6_0/> (often called 'drug reps' or, an older term, 'detail men') to market <a2_0><b5_0>directly and personally to physicians<b5_0/><a2_0/> and other healthcare providers. In some countries, notably the US, pharmaceutical companies also employ lobbyists to influence politicians. Marketing of prescription drugs in the US is regulated by <b7_0>the federal <a1_0><b4_0>Prescription Drug Marketing Act of 1987<b7_0/><b4_0/><a1_0/>.
